The Nasdaq Composite lost 0.5%.  “Traders are having second thoughts, it seems, about having run stocks up as much as they did last week,” writes Thierry Wizman, global FX and rates strategist at Macquarie Group.

^DJI.title: Wall Street ends lower, crypto stocks drop
^DJI.summary:
STORY: U.S. stocks closed lower on Monday, with the Dow losing nine-tenths of a percent, the S&P 500 shedding more than half a percent and the Nasdaq dropping over a third of a percent.

High stock valuations and the future path of interest rates continue to drive market action, says Melissa Brown, managing director of investment decision research at SimCorp.

“I think we've just been going back and forth between risk on days and risk off days. And it kind of suggests this underlying volatility that investors can't really make up their mind. And so they're just having a hard time. Today it's AI or today it's not AI. Tomorrow you know, it may be and or you know, it may also be, you know, the Fed and the back and forth. First of all, is the Fed going to lower rates? And second of all, if they lower rates, is that good news or bad news?"

Markets have largely priced in a December rate cut from the Fed. Despite those expectations, U.S. Treasury yields were higher on Monday, pressuring stocks.

Bitcoin also stumbled, at one point dropping below $85,000.

Shares of Strategy, formerly known as MicroStrategy and the world's largest holder of bitcoin, ended more than 3% lower after tumbling as much as 12%. It cut its earnings forecast for 2025, citing a weak run in bitcoin.

Crypto-related stocks Coinbase and Bitfarms also fell. 

Among other movers, Synopsys shares closed about 5% higher after AI chip leader Nvidia said it had invested $2 billion in the semiconductor design software provider.

^RUT.title: Russell 2000 Falls on Terrible Times
^RUT.summary: An index encapsulating the smallest U.S. companies by market value has been underperforming lately.  The small-cap Russell 2000 is down 3.5% over the past month, while large cap indexes--the Dow and S&P 500---are up 2.6% and 1.7%, respectively.  An index capturing emerging market companies, the MSCI EM, is up 0.5% while its counterpart, the FTSE All-World Developed is higher by 1.3%.

^RUT.title: Don’t Buy the Stock Market Dip. These Charts of Small-Cap and Semiconductor Stocks Explain Why.
^RUT.summary: Last Tuesday the  completed a bearish island reversal with a rare gap down of 2%.  The weekly doji candle on the  last week still looms large.  This candle often appears at inflection points when a prevailing trend is about to reverse.

^RUT.title: The Stock Market Is Tumbling. Here’s How to Play Defense.
^RUT.summary: When it comes to protecting a portfolio against a market correction, it may be better to load up on Treasuries–a lot of them–than defensive stocks.  The S&P 500 is up almost 17% this year and the Nasdaq Composite has gained more than 21%.  It would be understandable if investors chose to stick with what’s working: simply rotating into more traditionally defensive sectors like consumer staples, utilities, and healthcare, rather than fixed income.

^RUT.title: Russell 2000’s Very Bad Day
^RUT.summary: It was a bad day to be a small-cap stock. The Russell 2000 was the worst-performing of all four major indexes, sinking roughly 2.8% Thursday. Investors' doubts that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates next month are hitting shares of smaller companies, which are considered more sensitive to rate moves.

^VIX.summary: The market has staged an impressive rebound, but is in for more volatility.  The overarching up-and-down dynamic starts with the fact that sellers have been coming in near the market’s highs to knock stock prices lower because investors and traders know that the more artificial-intelligence spending happens today, the greater the likelihood that the spending will collapse tomorrow.  The  Cboe  Volatility Index, which shows the magnitude of expected swings in stock prices, hit 18 early Monday, down from about 26 in mid November but above its low for the year of about 14.

MARKET.title: Trump’s Potential Fed Chair Pick: How It Could Impact Interest Rates and ETFs
MARKET.summary: President Trump's recent comments regarding the Federal Reserve leadership have created uncertainty. Although Fed Chair Jerome Powell's term lasts until May 2026, Trump's criticism and potential nominee speculations caused market volatility. A new Fed chair aligned with Trump's views might compromise the Fed's independence. Markets anticipate faster rate cuts under a new chair. This outlook could benefit bond and fixed-income ETFs in the short term.
